turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I thought you were gonna get one for me.

turns.speaker: SISTER
turns.text: My parents won't be back till ten.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I'd like to talk to you, if I could.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: May be a few minutes. I gotta stick around here...

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Not since 1963, since it happened. Every kid in Haddonfield thinks this place is haunted.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Come on... A skunk could have killed it...

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I suppose I do seem a bit sinister for a doctor.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Looks like to me you're just plain scared.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I am.  I met him fifteen years ago. I was told there was nothing left, no conscience, no reason, no understanding, in even the most rudimentary sense, of life or death or right or wrong. I met this six- year-old boy with a blank, cold emotionless face and the blackest of eyes, the Devil's eyes. I spent eight years trying to reach him and another seven trying to keep him locked away when I realized what was living behind that boy's eyes was purely and simply... evil.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: He was here, earlier tonight, and he may be coming back. I'm going to wait for him.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: I keep thinking I should call the radio and TV stations...

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: If you do they'll be seeing him everywhere, on every street corner, in every house. Just tell your men to shut their mouths and open their eyes.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: I'll check back in an hour.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Nothing's going on. Just kids playing pranks, trick or treating, partying, getting high... I have the feeling you're way off on this...

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: You're not coming up with much to prove me wrong.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Well, it's going to take more than fancy talk to keep me up all night creeping around these bushes.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I watched him for fifteen years, sitting in a room staring at a wall, not seeing the wall, seeing past it, seeing THIS NIGHT. He's waited for it, inhumanly patient. Hour after hour, day after day, waiting for some silent, invisible alarm to trigger him. Death has arrived in your little town, sheriff. You can ignore it, or you can help me stop it.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: More fancy talk... You want to know what Haddonfield is? Families. Children, all lined up in rows, up and down these streets. You're telling me they're lined up for a slaughterhouse.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: I'll stay out with you tonight, Doctor, just on the chance that you're right. And if you are right, damn you for letting him out.

turns.speaker: BRACKETT
turns.text: Where were you? I went back to the Myers house...

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: I found the car! He's here!

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Three blocks down. Get in the car and go up that other street and then back down here. I'm going up the block.

turns.speaker: LYNDA
turns.text: It's totally insane! We have three new cheers to learn in the morning, the game in the afternoon, I get my hair done at five, and the dance is at eight. I'll be totally wiped out!

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: I think you have too much to do tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: As usual, I don't have anything to do.

turns.speaker: LYNDA
turns.text: It's your own fault and I don't feel sorry for you.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: I thought you were babysitting tonight.

turns.speaker: LYNDA
turns.text: The only reason she babysits is to have a place to...

turns.speaker: LYNDA
turns.text: Isn't that David Graham? He's cute.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Annie, some day you're going to get us all in deep trouble.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Nothing. I was just sitting down for the first time tonight.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: No. I thought she'd be home by now. She went to pick up Paul.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: They probably stopped off somewhere. Have her call me when she gets back. I've got Lyndsey here and I want to know what time to put her to bed.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Can we watch the monster movies?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Will you read to me? Can we make popcorn?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Lonnie Elam said never to go up there. Lonnie Elam said that's a haunted house. He said real awful stuff happened there once.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Lonnie Elam probably won't get out of the sixth grade.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I gotta go. I'll see you tonight.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: ..."how now, cried Arthur. 'Then no one may pass this way without a fight?' 'That is so,' answered the night in a bold and haughty manner..."

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: But king Arthur was always your favorite.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Mom doesn't like me to have them.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: 'Neutron Man'... 'Laser Man'... I can see why. 'Tarantula Man'...

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: I'm so embarrassed. I couldn't face him...

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What about the rest of my comic books?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Richie said he was coming after me tonight.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Do you believe everything that Richie tells you?

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Tommy, Halloween night is when you play tricks on people and scare them. It's all make believe.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I saw the bogyman. I saw him outside.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: We're no getting anywhere. All right, look, Tommy. The bogyman can only come out on Halloween night, right?

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: And I'm here tonight and I won't let him get to you.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Can we make the Jack-O-Lantern now?

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Tommy, stop it! You're scaring Lindsey.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: I said, stop it! There is no bogyman. There's nothing out there. If you don't stop all this, I'm turning off the TV and you go to bed.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Tommy, I want you to go back upstairs...

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Be quiet! Get Lindsey and get into the bedroom and lock the door!

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Now I want you to change your clothes, Tommy. We're going to take a walk outside.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: But you can't kill the bogyman.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Everybody has a good time tonight. Okay, kids, what do you want to do now?

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: You've had enough. Why don't we just sit down and watch the rest of this movie.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: There's nothing to be scared of now. Get changed.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Now, I want you to walk to the door, down the stairs and right out the front door.

turns.speaker: LAURIE
turns.text: Listen to me. I want you to walk down the street to the MacKensie's and knock on their door. You tell them to call the police and send them over here. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hi, Lindsey, this is Paul. Is Annie there?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Will you get her for me?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, go tell her it's me, okay?

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: You must have told them we shocked him into a grinning idiot. Two roadblocks and an all-points bulletin wouldn't stop a five-year-old!

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: He was your patient, Doctor. If the precautions weren't sufficient, you should have notified...

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: There's nothing else I can do.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: You can get back on the telephone and tell them exactly what walked out of here last night. And tell them where he's going.

turns.speaker: WYNN
turns.text: Sam, Haddonfield is a hundred and fifty miles from here. How could he get there? He can't drive.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: He was doing all right last night. Maybe somebody around here gave him lessons.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: ...then he gets another physical by the state, and he makes his appearance before the judge. That should take four hours if we're lucky, then we're on our way.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: He'll barely be able to sit up.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: That's the idea. Here we are.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: The driveway's a few hundred yards up on your right.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Just try to understand what we're dealing with here. Don't underestimate it.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I think we should refer to 'it' as 'him.'

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: Ever done anything like this before?

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: You don't have to make this harder than it already is.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: The only thin that ever bothers me is their jibberish. When they start raving on and on...

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: You don't have anything to worry about. He hasn't spoken a word in 15 years.

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: He asked me if I could help him find his purple lawnmower.

turns.speaker: MARION
turns.text: I don't think this is any time to be funny...

turns.speaker: LOOMIS
turns.text: He said something else. "It's all right now. He's gone. The evil's gone."

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: ...because there are no interesting single men at this party!

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Hm-mm.  Oh, yeah.  I met Phil.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: He's the--He looks like Ichabod Crane?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I love that.  That's my type.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: We need more bread and some baked lasa--  uh, lasagne.  Hi.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: I know.  You're an actress with a great flair for shrimp puffs.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Uh, no, the shrimp puffs are Holly's.  I do the, uh, crêpes caviar.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: And the quail is responsible for the quail eggs.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Wha--  What kind of things do you build?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You know, April, people pass by vital structures in this city all the time, and they never take the time to appreciate them.  I get the feeling you tune in to your environment.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: What are your favorite buildings, David?

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: No, really, I really like him a lot.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: No, really, we mustn't get discouraged.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Hannah will invite some men over who don't look like Ichabod Crane.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Oh, in this we're a big hit. Yesterday I auditioned for Come Back Little Sheba.  That, I wasn't such a big hit.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Oh, is that what it is?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Uh-- APRIL  I-i-it has an o-organic quality, you know.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: It's almost...almost, uhhh, entirely wholly interdependent, if you know what I mean.  I-I... I can't put it into words.  The important thing is-is-is it-it breathes.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: It's French, though.  It really is.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: It feels like you're in France.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Well...we have seen a lot of stuff today, though.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Yeah, I, we both live downtown.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: It depends on what way you want to go.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Well, wait.  You know what?  I know.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: If...well, if we took the, if we took Fifth, then-then-then we'd get to your house first, yeah?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I mean, it's jammed.  If we went... um...

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I'm telling you, you sounded great. You, uh, you may be surprised.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Oh, I'm just glad we have a catering job this week.  I'm real low on money.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Yeah, we have Mr. Morris Levine's eightieth birthday party on Riverside Drive...or Riverside Memorial Chapel, depending on his health.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Oh, uh, listen, David called me up.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Uh, David called me last night, and he wants to take me to the opera.  I didn't know what to say.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: No, he called late last night.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: He wants to take me to see Rigoletto.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Well, I-I-I didn't know what to say. First I said no, but then, he pressed it.  He said, uh, he'd taken you once and he really wanted to invite me.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: I know.  I said that, but...  he said it was something he really felt like doing.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Gee, um...  I...I don't know what to say.

turns.speaker: APRIL
turns.text: Look, it's just an evening at the opera.  Did I, I-I do wrong in accepting?

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Oh, that was a wonderful show.  I think that's the best show you two ever wrote.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: No, the funniest show that Mickey and I ever did was the one we won the Emmy for.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Yeah, it was funny, it was very funny.  But the show was about the two Frenchmen, now that was funny and it was warm.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: We got that idea on that trip to Paris.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Do you remember that summer in France?  Hannah, you had jet lag for six straight weeks.

turns.speaker: NORMAN
turns.text: I gave blood before and, uh... clothing to the poor.

turns.speaker: CAROL
turns.text: Okay, Norman, listen, I really want to talk about this at home.  I think it's a matter for your analyst...and mine.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Excuse me, are there any more claims?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Only a few.  A few.  Do you like 'em?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Really?  How flattering!  Did you try the shrimp puffs?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Listen, you guys are too attractive to be caterers.  Something's wrong.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Really?  Is the food that bad?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Here, I stole you a couple of extra clams.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Yeah, we're the Stanislavski Catering Company.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Now I'm going to tell you the truth. I really came in here because I was bored stiff by the party.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: What makes you think we're more interesting?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: We saw, um, Pavarotti, eh, uh, in Ernani at the Met, and I cried...

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Oh, what, what do you do?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: What time do you get off?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: The design's deliberately noncontextural.  But I wanted to... keep the atmosphere of the street, you know, and the proportions.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: And in the material. That's...that's unpolished red granite.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Oh, it's just so romantic.  I just want to put on a long gown...

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: ...and open the French doors and go on the balcony --

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: And it's got a handsome partner sitting right beside it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: They fit right in together.  And your eye goes along, lulled into complacency, and then...

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Maybe we should start thinking about going home, huh?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Oh, gee, I don't know.  Um...

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Right.  Yeah, but Fifth is so jammed, isn't it?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Y-you live in Chelsea, don't you?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Well, I-I guess if you live in Chelsea, that's probably first.

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: So what's the, uh, problem this time?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: This time I really think I have something.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: So, so, but it was when I was younger, so--

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: You know, I saw your father this week about his sinus...

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: ...and, uh, he complained of chest pains.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Well, this guy's the real hypochondriac of the family.  I mean, he's, you know, he's--

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: You mentioned on the phone that you'd had some dizziness.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Yes, a little dizziness, and I think, I think I'm developing a hearing loss in my right ear  ...or my left ear, my, my left...oh, n-n-n-no.  No, I'm sorry.  It was my right, my right, my right or my left ear.

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry to say you have had a significant drop in the high- decibel range of your right ear.

turns.speaker: DR. ABEL
turns.text: Have you been exposed to a loud noise recently, or did you have a virus?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: No, I-I've been perfectly healthy. You know me.
